NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR LONDON – Orson Welles' Citizen Kane no longer enjoys the moniker of greatest film of all time, a plaudit it has held for 50 years. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The movie has occupied top billing in the British Film Institute-published magazine Sight & Sound's once-a-decade international critics’ film poll since 1962. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR PHOTOS: Redbox's Top 10 Most-Rented Movies of 2011: THR Year in Review NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But that crown, according to Sight & Sound's 2012 survey of 846 movie experts who participate, has now passed to Alfred Hitchcock’s Vertigo. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Made in 1958, the psychological suspense drama first entered the Sight & Sound poll in 1982 in seventh place -- two years after its director died. Largely ignored by the critics for most of his career, its rise in the poll is testament to how Hitchcock’s reputation has steadily increased over time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Starring James Stewart and Kim Novak, Vertigo trumped Citizen Kane by 34 votes this time around; it finished second 10 years ago, five votes shy of Kane. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And 1941's Kane, second in the survey, also missed out on the top spot in a separate poll of 358 film directors from all over the world -- including Martin Scorsese, Quentin Tarantino, Francis Ford Coppola, Woody Allen and Mike Leigh -- whose survey chose Yasujiro Ozu’s Tokyo Story (1953) as its greatest. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The critics poll, first conducted in 1952, marks the magazine's seventh and its most ambitious to date. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The 10-yearly survey aims to rule out fluctuations in taste and asks participants to interpret "greatest" in any way they choose. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR STORY: 'The Artist' Director Responds to Kim Novak Slam Over 'Vertigo' Music NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR That could mean whether the film was most important to film history, represented the aesthetic pinnacle of achievement or perhaps had a personal impact on their own view of cinema. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This year’s poll sample of 846 film critics, academics, distributors, writers and programmers from all corners of the globe was the biggest ever. They voted for 2,045 movie titles overall. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR That compares with the 144 who were asked 10 years ago. The pollsters said the huge increase "reflects the impact of the Internet and proliferation and increased influence of film commentators using this new medium." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Another fallout from this year's top 10 is Sergei Eisenstein's Battleship Potemkin, a 1925 film that has appeared in the top 10 for all of the poll's 60 years in various slots. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Three silent films make 2012's top 10: Dziga Vertov’s documentary Man With a Movie Camera (1929) is a new addition, while 1927's Sunrise, directed by F.W. Murnau, moves up to fifth and 1927's The Passion of Joan of Arc re-enters – ousting Potemkin. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Organizers said the changes might be explained by the availability of the films on DVD and the resurgence in popularity in recent years for different kinds of live accompaniment to the films, from The Alloy Orchestra and Michael Nyman to prog rock. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ozu’s Tokyo Story is in third spot and Jean Renoir’s La Règle du jeu (1939) occupies fourth. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Vertov’s film is the first documentary to make the top 10 since 1952. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Carl Theodor Dreyer’s Passion of Joan of Arc is ninth , while the most recent film in the top 10 is Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) in sixth place. John Ford's The Searchers (1956) hits the seventh spot, while Federico Fellini's 8 1/2 (1963) lies 10th.
